clean_story:
"Instant photos. No darkroom needed.
Polaroid’s name comes from ‘polarized light,’ a trick Edwin Land used to make cameras work faster.

Most people think of Polaroid as a fun, retro camera. But its real magic was chemistry. Inside every Polaroid film pack, tiny pods of chemicals burst when squeezed by rollers. In 60 seconds, a blank sheet turned into a photo—like a toaster popping up toast, but with images.

Edwin Land, the inventor, got the idea in 1943 when his daughter asked why she couldn’t see a photo right away. By 1948, the first Polaroid camera, the Model 95, sold for $89. 75 (about $1,100 today). It used separate positive/negative sheets that peeled apart like a sticker.

The SX-70 (1972) was the breakthrough. No waste. No peeling. Photos ejected and developed in daylight—a feat no other camera could do. Its folding design made it pocket-sized when closed.

Polaroid’s decline came with digital cameras. But its instant charm never faded. Today, The Impossible Project (now Polaroid Originals) keeps the film alive.

Three related subjects are Kodak’s film wars, how cameras stole light, and why analog tech survives. "
